intro: Lepidium linoides var. subdentatum, commonly known as the narrow-leaved peppergrass, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many economically important crops and weeds. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and has small, lance-shaped leaves with finely toothed margins. Its flowers are yellow and arranged in racemes, and it produces small, round pods that contain several seeds. This variety is distinguished by its narrower leaves compared to other varieties within the Lepidium genus.
